natural problem: Four people sit around a circular table, and each person will roll a standard six-sided die. What is the probability that no two people sitting next to each other will roll the same number after they each roll the die once? Express your answer as a common fraction.
natural solution: Consider the people around the table, sequentially, to be A, B, C and D. Now, with probability $\frac{1}{6}$, persons A and C, seated opposite one another, will roll the same number. In that case, each of B and D may roll any of 5 numbers not equal to the number rolled by both A and C. So the probability of no two consecutive persons rolling the same number in the case where A and C roll the same is $\frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{5}{6} \cdot \frac{5}{6}$.
A and C roll differently with probability $\frac{5}{6}$, in which case each of B and D must choose from only 4 numbers, because A and C offer different numbers to be avoided.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "real"
assumes h0 : "1 * probability = 35 / 72"
shows  "4 * probability = 35 * (1 / 6) * (1 / 6) * (1 / 6) * (1 / 6)"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Four people sit around a circular table, and each person will roll a standard six-sided die. What is the probability that no two people sitting next to each other will roll the same number after they each roll the die once? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{35}{72}
 ### Proof
 Consider the people around the table, sequentially, to be A, B, C and D. Now, with probability $\frac{1}{6}$, persons A and C, seated opposite one another, will roll the same number. In that case, each of B and D may roll any of 5 numbers not equal to the number rolled by both A and C. So the probability of no two consecutive persons rolling the same number in the case where A and C roll the same is $\frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{5}{6} \cdot \frac{5}{6}$.
 A and C roll differently with probability $\frac{5}{6}$, in which case each of B and D must choose from only 4 numbers, because A and C offer different numbers to be avoided.
 So, the probability then is $\frac{5}{6} \cdot \frac{4}{6} \cdot \frac{4}{6}$.
 Adding the two cases gives $\frac{5(5 + 4 \cdot 4)}{6^3} = \frac{3 \cdot 5 \cdot 7}{3 \cdot 2 \cdot 36} = \boxed{\frac{35}{72}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "real"
assumes h0 : "1 * probability = 35 / 72"
shows  "4 * probability = 35 * (1 / 6) * (1 / 6) * (1 / 6) * (1 / 6)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: If the probability of an event occurring is $\frac{35}{72}$, find the probability that the event occurs 4 times in a row. The final answer is $35 \times \left(\frac{1}{6}\right)^4$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<Prod>_{i = 1}^4 (1 - (i - 1) / 6))"
shows  "probability = 35 / 72"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Four people sit around a circular table, and each person will roll a standard six-sided die. What is the probability that no two people sitting next to each other will roll the same number after they each roll the die once? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{35}{72}
 ### Proof
 Consider the people around the table, sequentially, to be A, B, C and D. Now, with probability $\frac{1}{6}$, persons A and C, seated opposite one another, will roll the same number. In that case, each of B and D may roll any of 5 numbers not equal to the number rolled by both A and C. So the probability of no two consecutive persons rolling the same number in the case where A and C roll the same is $\frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{5}{6} \cdot \frac{5}{6}$.
 A and C roll differently with probability $\frac{5}{6}$, in which case each of B and D must choose from only 4 numbers, because A and C offer different numbers to be avoided.
 So, the probability then is $\frac{5}{6} \cdot \frac{4}{6} \cdot \frac{4}{6}$.
 Adding the two cases gives $\frac{5(5 + 4 \cdot 4)}{6^3} = \frac{3 \cdot 5 \cdot 7}{3 \cdot 2 \cdot 36} = \boxed{\frac{35}{72}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<Prod>_{i = 1}^4 (1 - (i - 1) / 6))"
shows  "probability = 35 / 72"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the probability of a certain event occurring, where the probability is given by the product of $(1 - \frac{i - 1}{6})$ for $i$ from 1 to 4. The final answer is $\frac{35}{72}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real set"
assumes h0 : "finite P"
and h1 : "card P = 6"
and h2 : "prob_space P"
and h3 : "indep_events (\<lambda>i. {x \<in> P. x = i}) {1,2,3,4}"
shows  "prob ({p \<in> P \<times> P \<times> P \<times> P. \<forall>i j. (i \<noteq> j \<and> i \<noteq> j + 1 \<and> i \<noteq> j - 1) \<longrightarrow> fst p \<noteq> fst (snd p) \<and> fst (snd p) \<noteq> fst (snd (snd p)) \<and> fst (snd (snd p)) \<noteq> fst (snd (snd (snd p))) \<and> fst (snd (snd (snd p))) \<noteq> fst p}) = 35 / 72"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Four people sit around a circular table, and each person will roll a standard six-sided die. What is the probability that no two people sitting next to each other will roll the same number after they each roll the die once? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{35}{72}
 ### Proof
 Consider the people around the table, sequentially, to be A, B, C and D. Now, with probability $\frac{1}{6}$, persons A and C, seated opposite one another, will roll the same number. In that case, each of B and D may roll any of 5 numbers not equal to the number rolled by both A and C. So the probability of no two consecutive persons rolling the same number in the case where A and C roll the same is $\frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{5}{6} \cdot \frac{5}{6}$.
 A and C roll differently with probability $\frac{5}{6}$, in which case each of B and D must choose from only 4 numbers, because A and C offer different numbers to be avoided.
 So, the probability then is $\frac{5}{6} \cdot \frac{4}{6} \cdot \frac{4}{6}$.
 Adding the two cases gives $\frac{5(5 + 4 \cdot 4)}{6^3} = \frac{3 \cdot 5 \cdot 7}{3 \cdot 2 \cdot 36} = \boxed{\frac{35}{72}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real set"
assumes h0 : "finite P"
and h1 : "card P = 6"
and h2 : "prob_space P"
and h3 : "indep_events (\<lambda>i. {x \<in> P. x = i}) {1,2,3,4}"
shows  "prob ({p \<in> P \<times> P \<times> P \<times> P. \<forall>i j. (i \<noteq> j \<and> i \<noteq> j + 1 \<and> i \<noteq> j - 1) \<longrightarrow> fst p \<noteq> fst (snd p) \<and> fst (snd p) \<noteq> fst (snd (snd p)) \<and> fst (snd (snd p)) \<noteq> fst (snd (snd (snd p))) \<and> fst (snd (snd (snd p))) \<noteq> fst p}) = 35 / 72"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: In a probability space with a finite set $P$ of 6 elements, four independent events are chosen from the set $\{1, 2, 3, 4\}$. What is the probability that none of the four events are equal, and no two consecutive events are chosen? The final answer is $\frac{35}{72}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "rat"
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> probability \<and> probability \<le> 1"
and h1 : "probability = (35 / 72)"
shows  "probability = (35 / 72)"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Four people sit around a circular table, and each person will roll a standard six-sided die. What is the probability that no two people sitting next to each other will roll the same number after they each roll the die once? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{35}{72}
 ### Proof
 Consider the people around the table, sequentially, to be A, B, C and D. Now, with probability $\frac{1}{6}$, persons A and C, seated opposite one another, will roll the same number. In that case, each of B and D may roll any of 5 numbers not equal to the number rolled by both A and C. So the probability of no two consecutive persons rolling the same number in the case where A and C roll the same is $\frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{5}{6} \cdot \frac{5}{6}$.
 A and C roll differently with probability $\frac{5}{6}$, in which case each of B and D must choose from only 4 numbers, because A and C offer different numbers to be avoided.
 So, the probability then is $\frac{5}{6} \cdot \frac{4}{6} \cdot \frac{4}{6}$.
 Adding the two cases gives $\frac{5(5 + 4 \cdot 4)}{6^3} = \frac{3 \cdot 5 \cdot 7}{3 \cdot 2 \cdot 36} = \boxed{\frac{35}{72}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "rat"
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> probability \<and> probability \<le> 1"
and h1 : "probability = (35 / 72)"
shows  "probability = (35 / 72)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: What is the probability of an event occurring if it is given to be $\frac{35}{72}$? Assume the probability is a rational number between 0 and 1. The final answer is $\frac{35}{72}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = 35 / 72"
shows  "p = (4 * 5 * 6 - 4 * (6 powr 2)) / (6 powr 4)"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Four people sit around a circular table, and each person will roll a standard six-sided die. What is the probability that no two people sitting next to each other will roll the same number after they each roll the die once? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{35}{72}
 ### Proof
 Consider the people around the table, sequentially, to be A, B, C and D. Now, with probability $\frac{1}{6}$, persons A and C, seated opposite one another, will roll the same number. In that case, each of B and D may roll any of 5 numbers not equal to the number rolled by both A and C. So the probability of no two consecutive persons rolling the same number in the case where A and C roll the same is $\frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{5}{6} \cdot \frac{5}{6}$.
 A and C roll differently with probability $\frac{5}{6}$, in which case each of B and D must choose from only 4 numbers, because A and C offer different numbers to be avoided.
 So, the probability then is $\frac{5}{6} \cdot \frac{4}{6} \cdot \frac{4}{6}$.
 Adding the two cases gives $\frac{5(5 + 4 \cdot 4)}{6^3} = \frac{3 \cdot 5 \cdot 7}{3 \cdot 2 \cdot 36} = \boxed{\frac{35}{72}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = 35 / 72"
shows  "p = (4 * 5 * 6 - 4 * (6 powr 2)) / (6 powr 4)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Calculate the value of $p$ given by the expression $p = \frac{4 \times 5 \times 6 - 4 \times (6^2)}{6^4}$. The final answer is $\frac{35}{72}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: real
assumes h0 : "P = (\<Sum>i\<in>{1..6}. (\<Sum>j\<in>{1..6}. (\<Sum>k\<in>{1..6}. (\<Sum>l\<in>{1..6}. 
  (if i \<noteq> j \<and> j \<noteq> k \<and> k \<noteq> l \<and> l \<noteq> i then 1 else 0)))) / (6 * 6 * 6 * 6))"
shows  "P = 35 / 72"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Four people sit around a circular table, and each person will roll a standard six-sided die. What is the probability that no two people sitting next to each other will roll the same number after they each roll the die once? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{35}{72}
 ### Proof
 Consider the people around the table, sequentially, to be A, B, C and D. Now, with probability $\frac{1}{6}$, persons A and C, seated opposite one another, will roll the same number. In that case, each of B and D may roll any of 5 numbers not equal to the number rolled by both A and C. So the probability of no two consecutive persons rolling the same number in the case where A and C roll the same is $\frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{5}{6} \cdot \frac{5}{6}$.
 A and C roll differently with probability $\frac{5}{6}$, in which case each of B and D must choose from only 4 numbers, because A and C offer different numbers to be avoided.
 So, the probability then is $\frac{5}{6} \cdot \frac{4}{6} \cdot \frac{4}{6}$.
 Adding the two cases gives $\frac{5(5 + 4 \cdot 4)}{6^3} = \frac{3 \cdot 5 \cdot 7}{3 \cdot 2 \cdot 36} = \boxed{\frac{35}{72}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: real
assumes h0 : "P = (\<Sum>i\<in>{1..6}. (\<Sum>j\<in>{1..6}. (\<Sum>k\<in>{1..6}. (\<Sum>l\<in>{1..6}. 
  (if i \<noteq> j \<and> j \<noteq> k \<and> k \<noteq> l \<and> l \<noteq> i then 1 else 0)))) / (6 * 6 * 6 * 6))"
shows  "P = 35 / 72"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Find the probability $P$ that when rolling four 6-sided dice, no two dice show the same number. Express your answer as a common fraction. The final answer is $\frac{35}{72}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (35 / 72)"
shows  "P = probability (\<lambda>outcome. \<not> (\<exists>i \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4}. outcome i = outcome ((i + 1) mod 4)))"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Four people sit around a circular table, and each person will roll a standard six-sided die. What is the probability that no two people sitting next to each other will roll the same number after they each roll the die once? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{35}{72}
 ### Proof
 Consider the people around the table, sequentially, to be A, B, C and D. Now, with probability $\frac{1}{6}$, persons A and C, seated opposite one another, will roll the same number. In that case, each of B and D may roll any of 5 numbers not equal to the number rolled by both A and C. So the probability of no two consecutive persons rolling the same number in the case where A and C roll the same is $\frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{5}{6} \cdot \frac{5}{6}$.
 A and C roll differently with probability $\frac{5}{6}$, in which case each of B and D must choose from only 4 numbers, because A and C offer different numbers to be avoided.
 So, the probability then is $\frac{5}{6} \cdot \frac{4}{6} \cdot \frac{4}{6}$.
 Adding the two cases gives $\frac{5(5 + 4 \cdot 4)}{6^3} = \frac{3 \cdot 5 \cdot 7}{3 \cdot 2 \cdot 36} = \boxed{\frac{35}{72}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (35 / 72)"
shows  "P = probability (\<lambda>outcome. \<not> (\<exists>i \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4}. outcome i = outcome ((i + 1) mod 4)))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find the probability that in a sequence of four outcomes, no two consecutive outcomes are the same. The final answer is $\frac{35}{72}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<Sum>i\<in>{0..5}. (5 - i) * (6 - i) * (6 - i) * (6 - i)) / 6 powr 4"
shows  "probability = 35 / 72"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Four people sit around a circular table, and each person will roll a standard six-sided die. What is the probability that no two people sitting next to each other will roll the same number after they each roll the die once? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{35}{72}
 ### Proof
 Consider the people around the table, sequentially, to be A, B, C and D. Now, with probability $\frac{1}{6}$, persons A and C, seated opposite one another, will roll the same number. In that case, each of B and D may roll any of 5 numbers not equal to the number rolled by both A and C. So the probability of no two consecutive persons rolling the same number in the case where A and C roll the same is $\frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{5}{6} \cdot \frac{5}{6}$.
 A and C roll differently with probability $\frac{5}{6}$, in which case each of B and D must choose from only 4 numbers, because A and C offer different numbers to be avoided.
 So, the probability then is $\frac{5}{6} \cdot \frac{4}{6} \cdot \frac{4}{6}$.
 Adding the two cases gives $\frac{5(5 + 4 \cdot 4)}{6^3} = \frac{3 \cdot 5 \cdot 7}{3 \cdot 2 \cdot 36} = \boxed{\frac{35}{72}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<Sum>i\<in>{0..5}. (5 - i) * (6 - i) * (6 - i) * (6 - i)) / 6 powr 4"
shows  "probability = 35 / 72"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Find the probability of the following event: in a sequence of six independent rolls of a fair six-sided die, the sum of the numbers rolled is equal to the sum of the numbers from 0 to 5. Express your answer as a common fraction. The final answer is $\frac{35}{72}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob_adj_same :: real and prob_not_adj_same :: real
assumes h0 : "prob_adj_same = 1 / 6"
and h1 : "prob_not_adj_same = 1 - prob_adj_same"
and h2 : "prob_not_adj_same powr 4 = (35 / 72)"
shows  "prob_not_adj_same = 35 / 72"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Four people sit around a circular table, and each person will roll a standard six-sided die. What is the probability that no two people sitting next to each other will roll the same number after they each roll the die once? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{35}{72}
 ### Proof
 Consider the people around the table, sequentially, to be A, B, C and D. Now, with probability $\frac{1}{6}$, persons A and C, seated opposite one another, will roll the same number. In that case, each of B and D may roll any of 5 numbers not equal to the number rolled by both A and C. So the probability of no two consecutive persons rolling the same number in the case where A and C roll the same is $\frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{5}{6} \cdot \frac{5}{6}$.
 A and C roll differently with probability $\frac{5}{6}$, in which case each of B and D must choose from only 4 numbers, because A and C offer different numbers to be avoided.
 So, the probability then is $\frac{5}{6} \cdot \frac{4}{6} \cdot \frac{4}{6}$.
 Adding the two cases gives $\frac{5(5 + 4 \cdot 4)}{6^3} = \frac{3 \cdot 5 \cdot 7}{3 \cdot 2 \cdot 36} = \boxed{\frac{35}{72}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes prob_adj_same :: real and prob_not_adj_same :: real
assumes h0 : "prob_adj_same = 1 / 6"
and h1 : "prob_not_adj_same = 1 - prob_adj_same"
and h2 : "prob_not_adj_same powr 4 = (35 / 72)"
shows  "prob_not_adj_same = 35 / 72"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given that the probability of two events occurring adjacently is $\frac{1}{6}$, find the probability of them not occurring adjacently, if the probability of the latter raised to the power of 4 equals $\frac{35}{72}$. The final answer is $\frac{35}{72}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: real
assumes h0 : "P = (\<lambda>n. (1 / 6) ^ n)"
and h1 : "P = (\<lambda>m. (1 / 6) ^ m)"
and h2 : "P = (\<lambda>k. (1 / 6) ^ k)"
and h3 : "P = (\<lambda>l. (1 / 6) ^ l)"
and h4 : "independent_events {P, Q, R, S}"
and h5 : "prob_space (P * Q * R * S)"
and h6 : "P (four_people_no_adjacent_same_roll) = 35 / 72"
shows  "P (four_people_no_adjacent_same_roll) = 35 / 72"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Four people sit around a circular table, and each person will roll a standard six-sided die. What is the probability that no two people sitting next to each other will roll the same number after they each roll the die once? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{35}{72}
 ### Proof
 Consider the people around the table, sequentially, to be A, B, C and D. Now, with probability $\frac{1}{6}$, persons A and C, seated opposite one another, will roll the same number. In that case, each of B and D may roll any of 5 numbers not equal to the number rolled by both A and C. So the probability of no two consecutive persons rolling the same number in the case where A and C roll the same is $\frac{1}{6} \cdot \frac{5}{6} \cdot \frac{5}{6}$.
 A and C roll differently with probability $\frac{5}{6}$, in which case each of B and D must choose from only 4 numbers, because A and C offer different numbers to be avoided.
 So, the probability then is $\frac{5}{6} \cdot \frac{4}{6} \cdot \frac{4}{6}$.
 Adding the two cases gives $\frac{5(5 + 4 \cdot 4)}{6^3} = \frac{3 \cdot 5 \cdot 7}{3 \cdot 2 \cdot 36} = \boxed{\frac{35}{72}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: real
assumes h0 : "P = (\<lambda>n. (1 / 6) ^ n)"
and h1 : "P = (\<lambda>m. (1 / 6) ^ m)"
and h2 : "P = (\<lambda>k. (1 / 6) ^ k)"
and h3 : "P = (\<lambda>l. (1 / 6) ^ l)"
and h4 : "independent_events {P, Q, R, S}"
and h5 : "prob_space (P * Q * R * S)"
and h6 : "P (four_people_no_adjacent_same_roll) = 35 / 72"
shows  "P (four_people_no_adjacent_same_roll) = 35 / 72"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: In a probability space, four people roll a fair six-sided die. Let $P$ be the probability of rolling a certain number, and let $Q$, $R$, and $S$ be the probabilities of rolling the next three numbers respectively. If the events are independent and the probability of no two adjacent people rolling the same number is $\frac{35}{72}$, show that the probability of this event occurring is indeed $\frac{35}{72}$.
